column3: Definition
The core entities on which longitudinal data will be collected. Each entity has a dated start and end event
A place to which geo-coordinates can be assigned
Village or other higher level spatial grouping of locations
Latitude and longitude on the WGS84 coordinate system

A household resident at a location within the boundary of the surveillance area. A household is defined as a social group of one or more individual members. Resident household members share the same dwelling as the household, non-resident household members are individuals who do not share the same dwelling as the household, but who eat from the same pot when they are present in the household‚Äôs dwelling.
A unique household identifier which the household retains irrespective of its current residence

Household members, where a resident is a member of a household who normally lives (i.e. intends to sleep the majority of the time) at the same dwelling as the household; and a non-resident is a member of a household who does not normally live at the same dwelling as the household but is nevertheless considered a member of the household.
A globally unique identifier used internally to uniquely identify the individual
An identifier used on data collection instruments to uniquely identify the individual, but is removed together with other personally identifiable information when data is made available for analysis
Family or last name
An alternative surname (formerly) used by the individual, e.g. maiden name
The first given name of the individual
The second/alternative given name of the individual
The 13-digit South African civilian identity number
The country of which the individual is a citizen
The country of origin of the individual (the country of which the person is/was a citizen by birth)
Male (1), female(2) or unknown(0)
The Birth event of this individual or the DeliveryEvent resulting in the birth of this individual if the individual enters surveillance through birth
The death event of this individual or the Observation at which this individual was last observed
The unique identifier of the mother of the individual, if the mother is enumerated in the surveillance
The unique identifier of the father of the individual, if the father is enumerated in the surveillance
The surname of the mother of the individual
The first name/s of the mother
The surname of the father of the individual
The first name/s of the father
Demographic events that delineate episodes of observation during longitudinal surveillance
A change in location of usual residence
Date of migration
Origin of the migration (location)
Destination of the migration (location)
Individual or household
The birth event of an individual
Date of birth
Birth weight as obtained from the Road to Health card in grams
Whether the birth certificate was observed
The date on which the birth was registered, or null if the birth hasn‚Äôt been registered yet
The end event of a pregnancy
Date of birth
Types i-ii is only applicable if the pregnancy end prior to the 28th week of pregnancy, types iii-v is applicable only on or after the 28th week of pregnancy
The number of babies born alive resulting from this delivery
The number of still born babies resulting from this delivery
The death of an individual
The date of the death
Observed

WHO standard verbal autopsy questionnaire items. SAPRIN will adopt the worldwide standardised World Health Organisation (WHO) Verbal Autopsy questionnaires to determine the cause of deaths reported in the surveillance population. The latest version of the WHO Verbal Autopsy Questionnaire is 2016, edited and cognitively tested to facilitate the use of publicly available analytical software for assigning the cause of death.
The initial event at enumeration of an entity. Can only be used during the base census of the demographic surveillance, or when a new area is added to the surveillance
Date of enumeration
A change in household membership
The date of the change
A change in the head of the household
The date of the change
A change in the union (conjugal relationship) between two individuals
The date of the event
A surveillance visit at a location
Visit date
Location where the visit took place
The person responsible for data collection during the visit
The primary respondent at the visit
Used to record associations longitudinally between base entities. Episodes are always started and ended through events.

An episode during which an individual is resident (sleeping most of the time there) at a particular location that falls within the surveillance area. An individual can only be resident at one location at a time, i.e. residency episodes cannot overlap
The individual identifier
The location identifier
The event that started the episode, can only be Enumeration, Birth, Migration (Direction: In)
The event that terminated the episode, can only be Death, Migration (Direction: Out) and Observation (in which the implication is that the individual is last known to be resident)

An episode during which a household is resident at a particular location that falls within the surveillance area. A household can only be resident at one location at a time, i.e. residency episodes cannot overlap
The household identifier
The location identifier
The identifier associated with the household during this residence
The event that started the episode, can only be Enumeration, Household formation, Migration (Direction: In)
The event that terminated the episode, can only be Household dissolution, Migration (Direction: Out) and Observation (in which the implication is that the household is last known to be resident)

An episode during which an individual is a member of a household. An individual must be a member of at least one household to be under surveillance. An individual can be a member of more than one household at a time (membership episodes may overlap). In the case of multiple memberships, the designated household of an individual will be the household the individual is co-resident with, ranked according to the closeness of the members relationship to the household head (self, spouse, child, grandchild, parent, sibling, other relationship)
The individual identifier
The household identifier
The event that started the episode, can only be Enumeration, Birth or Membership start
The event that ended the episode, can only be Death, Membership end or Observation (implying that the membership is current)

Household head relationships are linked to a household membership and record the relationship between the individual and the head of the associated household. If the head of household change, all current household members start a new household head relationship episode
The household membership episode associated with this household head relationship
The relationship between the individual member (to whom the membership belongs) and the current household head of the household
The event that started the episode. Can only be Enumeration, Birth, Membership start, or Household Headship start
The event that ended the episode. Can only be Death, Membership end, Household Headship end or Observation
The episode during which two persons are in an informal or formal conjugal relationship. For a conjugal relationship to exist the following factors should be considered:

column1: i. Shelter. Do the partners live under the same roof?
ii. Sexual and personal conduct. Do the partners have sexual relations; do they maintain an attitude of fidelity to each other; do they eat their meals together?
iii. Services. Do they share household responsibilities?
iv. Social. Do they participate together in social activities; does their society recognise them as a couple?
v. Support. Do they support each other financially?
vi. Children. Do they have children together?

column3: The individual identifier of one of the parties to the union. By convention this will be the female in a heterosexual union.
The individual identifier of the second party to the union.
The start of the union. Can only be Enumeration or Union start
The date on which the union has been formalised as a marriage
The end of the union. Can only be Union ‚Äì partner died, Union ‚Äì separation (if there is no marriage date), Union ‚Äì divorce (if there is a marriage date), or Observation if it a current union
The period of being pregnant. Also used to record maternity histories retrospectively
The individual identifier of the woman who experienced the pregnancy
The number of antenatal care visits during this pregnancy
Duration in weeks of the pregnancy
A delivery event or Observation if the pregnancy is still current at the time of observation
The period during which an individual receives a government social support grant
The individual identifier of the person holding the grant

The individual identifier of the intended beneficiary of the grant. This may be the same as the identifier of the grant holder in the case where the holder is the beneficiary, e.g. old age pension, or different as in the case of care dependency grants, where the grant holder receives the grant on behalf of someone else, e.g. a child
The type of grant
The start date of the social support
The end date of the social support

Information collected at a particular observation, valid only at the time of the observation. State may be imputed between consecutive status observations but is not known to be valid. This is in contrast with episode where the assertion is that the state represented by the episode is valid for the duration of the episode.
A set of data elements collected about an individual either during a face-to-face visit or telephonic interview with the individual or from a proxy informant
The unique individual identifier of the subject of the status observation
The observation at which the status observation was made
Physical presence in the dwelling, recorded as the number of months since the previous observation visit
Grade 1 ‚Äì 12
If the individual is currently attending an educational institution, at what level:
Type/reason for unemployment
Self-reported financial status
Self-reported health status
i. When last HIV- result (>1yr, <1yr ago)
HIV serostatus from dried blood spot
For each vaccination record: date received and source of information (Road to Health Card or recall)
Set of data elements collected from a household informant, during a face to face or telephonic interview
The most commonly used (during last year) source of drinking water
What kind of toilet does the household use
Is the household connected to the electricity grid?
What is the main fuel used for cooking?
What is the construction materials of the walls?

column1: What is the construction material of the floor?
How many bedrooms does your household occupy at this dwelling?

column3: Does the household have any of the following items in good working order?
Has any resident member of the household been a victim of any of these crimes in the past 12 months?
How would the household classify its financial situation these days?
In the last 12 months did you or any other member of your household ever cut the size of your meals or skip meals because there was not enough money for food?
